div.head: Drawings from the Tour of 1833
div.p: Drawings that Ruskin made during the Tour of 1833—and possibly, some of them, after the familyʼs return home—are listed here in topographical order according to the tour itinerary. I am grateful to Stephen Wildman for the basis of this list, which draws on holdings in libraries and galleries and on listings in catalogues. Several documented 1833 tour sketches can no longer be traced.

Omitted from this list are the drawings that Ruskin made as vignettes to illustrate Account of a Tour on the Continent, which occupied Ruskinʼs creative energy for about a year following the familyʼs return in September 1833 (see “Account”: Date); these vignettes are separately annotated as part of ERMʼs edition of the “Account”. The tour sketches are distinct from the vignettes in style and other features, even though Ruskin used the tour sketches as the basis for some of the vignettes, as explained in Account of a Tour on the Continent: Missing and Unidentified Drawings for the Composite‐Genre Illustrated Travelogue (MS IX) and Related 1833 Tour Sketches. The vignettes should be understood less as records of a tour, than as imitations of the visual media prevalent in the print culture of travel in the 1830s, whereby British readers consumed Continental scenery.

Despite this caveat, this list of tour sketches may perpetuate some confusion in earlier catalogues between what should be classified as tour sketches and what originated as vignettes for the “Account”. Too little is known especially about drawings in the list that can no longer be traced, some of which may have been vignettes intended for use directly in the fair‐copy version of the “Account” (MS IX), but which became separated from the manuscript or were never permanently affixed there. We know, for example, that in 1878 at the Fine Art Society Ruskin exhibited a drawing that was a version of Hôtel de Ville, Brussels, after Samuel Prout. It is not readily apparent whether this was the drawing presently associated with that title at the Ruskin Library, or a miniaturization of this subject--a vignette intended for MS IX--that has not been located (probably the latter: see Hôtel de Ville, Brussels; see also Missing and Unidentified Drawings for the Composite‐Genre Illustrated Travelogue (MS IX) and Related 1833 Tour Sketches).

Ruskin exhibited another 1833 drawing or group of drawings at the Fine Art Society in 1878, which he described as "a day's sketching . . . between Arona and Domo d'Ossola on the same journey" that he "finished out of my head" at some later time. Ruskin considered the work "interesting" for "proper economy of paper" and "weak enthusiasm" but especially for "fastening so early" on a landscape truth that he would illustrate more than two decades later in a drawing for Modern Painters IV, The Rock of Arona. In the chapter on "Precipices" among those on the "Sculpture of Mountains", he enforces understanding of "real rock lines" that follow a "parabolic flow" in overhanging rock forms, and outline a "delicate overhanging . . . cautiously diminished as [the precipice] gets higher", as compared with the fantastic precipice forms invented by Claude Lorrain and Renaissance painters, who were "fond of representing . . . overhanging of rocks with buildings on the top, and weeds drooping into the air over the edge, always thinking to get sublimity by exaggerating the projection" (Ruskin, Works, 13:505; 6:310-11 and pl. 41). What adumbration of this mountain truth Ruskin found in his early drawing of the precipice above Arona can no longer be examined since the location of the drawing is unknown. The editors of the Library Edition named the drawing as Lago Maggiore and Domo dʼOssola, and associated it with a pencil drawing then owned by Mrs. Cunliffe. (In his plate Lago Maggiore, William Brockedon shows in the distance "on the borders of the lake, the overhanging precipice beneath which the route of the Simplon passes to Arona", and beneath which "it is difficult to pass . . . without feeling an emotion of danger" [Brockedon, Illustrations of the Passes of the Alps, “The Pass of the Simplon”, 17, 18]). Atop the precipice, impressively but not improbably situated, stands the Rocca di Arona, a fortress owned by the Borromeo family. When viewed by the Ruskins, the fortress was a ruin, destroyed by Napoleon's army in 1800.)

Two 1833–34 drawings that cannot be located—[“Watch‐tower at Andernach”], and [“The Jungfrau from Interlaken”]—are preserved in facsimile by photogravure. Since these survive in nineteenth‐century reproductions that, according to W. G. Collingwood (Poems [4o, 1891], 1:vii), preserve the originalsʼ dimensions, the Andernach drawing is listed here as a tour drawing: as reproduced, it would have been too large to have served as a vignette illustration for MS IX. The reproduction of the Interlaken (Switzerland) drawing, however, indicates an original of the appropriate size and shape for a vignette illustration, and its probable intended location in the “Account” can be identified: this photogravured vignette is therefore omitted here and instead treated in its place as a part of the "Account".

It is ironic that the originals of these photogravures vanished in a process of reproduction that, in W. G. Collingwoodʼs characterization, was driven by a desire for authenticity. According to his “Prefatory Notes on the Plates” in the 1891 edition of Ruskinʼs Poems, Collingwood along with the “publisher, engravers, and printers” was motivated by an “anxiety . . . that the plates should represent the original drawings as accurately as modern skill permits”. As a foil, Collingwood characterizes the “old standard art” of engraving used to illustrate Ruskinʼs earlier books as a “joint” project of designer and engraver, like “concerted music” performed by “players on different instruments”. An authentic solo performance by the designer was not reproducible on a mass scale; “it was never . . . [the artist and engraverʼs] intention to give the style and touch of the draughtsman, his separate individuality, his momentary mood, as shown in the very material and handling of the original sketch”. Now this authentic individuality had come within reach of reproducibility, it seemed, with the invention “of modern photographic engraving”, which Collingwood regards as an attempt “to reproduce the master, to facsimile the authentic document”. The means of reproduction aligns with Collingwoodʼs biographically oriented editorial aims: “this is what we want here in such pictures as rightly illustrate a collection of Poems written in Youth, in bygone historic times, recording a famous manʼs childhood and boyhood, his first impressions and fresh ideas of the world and of life”. Photographic engraving promises to supply “genuine records of the traditional precocity which we should like to verify: some true measure of the progress which we suspect, but cannnot otherwise trace, by which genius was developed. We want to see Ruskinʼs drawings, and not engraverʼs plates” (Poems [4o, 1891], 1:v).

In the 1891 Poems (large‐paper edition only, the octavo edition containing no plates), the “Prefatory Notes on the Plates” complements the “Preliminary Note on the Original MSS. of the Poems”, but the former was placed at the front of volume one, and the latter at its end, presumably because the physical witnesses of the photogravure plates were regarded as the closest possible encounter with the actuality of Ruskinʼs youth. Comparatively, the edited and printed poems placed the material manuscripts at a step removed, mediated by the editor, although some compensation was afforded by photogravure reproduction of samples of Ruskinʼs early handwriting, as well. Collingwood admits that “no reproduction can be quite the same thing as an original, if the original owe any of its interest to the more subtle artistic qualities of line and tone”. The benefit of photogravure, in Collingwoodʼs mind, lay in its “mechanical reproduction by a method which, clever and charming as it is, adds nothing to . . . [the sketchesʼ] cleverness and charm”—the mechanization assuring that what was conveyed was at least purely authentic, however deficient otherwise. Collingwood evidently perceived no significant contradiction between this faith in mechanization and his admission that “Messrs. Walker and Boutallʼs photogravures” were “helped by Mr. George Allenʼs retouching” (Poems [4o, 1891], 1:vi). But what seemed comparatively to liberate reproduction of an artifact from human intervention in the 1890s now seems quaintly like handicraft. From a twenty‐first century perspective, the early stage of “photogravure was a hand process”; the skill incorporated the eighteenth‐century technique of aquatint, and “early attempts to print photographs in ink often included efforts to retain . . . [the] capacity to manipulate the image” through “intrusions of handwork” (Benson, The Printed Picture, 236, 232).

In the following list, titles cited with quotation marks refer to captions that Ruskin wrote directly on the tour sketch, and titles cited with quotation marks inside square brackets refer to captions devised by W. G. Collingwood. Titles that are not Ruskinʼs, or that cannot be definitely traced to him, are cited without quotation marks. Citations of Ruskin, Works, volume 38, refer to the “Catalogue of Ruskinʼs Drawings” compiled for the Library Edition (38:215–306); citations of Collingwood, Life and Work of John Ruskin, refer to the “Catalogue of Drawings by Mr. Ruskin (1829–1859)” (1:238–43); and citations of Collingwood, Ruskin Exhibition, refer to the catalogue of the Ruskin Exhibition, Coniston, 1900.

div.p: A drawing described in Ruskin, Works, 38:260 (no. 939), as Landeck (pencil; provenance, Mrs. Cunliffe), must have been misidentified or misdated, since the Ruskins did not travel to the Tyrol in 1833. The date of this drawing is corrected to 21 September 1835 and identified in Hanley and Hull, ed., John Ruskinʼs Continental Tour 1835, 228 (no. 96).
